job_title: Consultant in Valencia, CA
pros: Not much to say...it's close to home for most who work there because no one will drive farther. There's so much turnover that there are always job openings.
cons:
Management is dishonest with company finances, business dealings, handling key issues and constantly brushes issues under the rug. There are no solid HR policies. 
The best employees are disgruntled and don't speak out for fear of retaliation. There's so much back stabbing and discrimination among the staff that  it shows in the poor patient care. Employees are more concerned about popularity and putting down co workers who are "heavier, less attractive, don't drive the popular car or use the latest cell phones" that they don't put effort into caring for the patients. The theme is constantly "that's not my job"... No one wants to take responsibility or action until there's a crisis, in which case, they blame someone else or harassment of hard workers occurs. 
Medical equipment  and technology is poorly maintained yet published as if it's top of the line. Medical staff abuse substances and do unthinkable acts on company time.  This I've seen with my own eyes.
This is real and there are countless law suits to prove it. 
Employee benefits are horrendous. You get worse care than what you are paid to provide.
Patient accounts and billing are mishandled and vulnerable patients are constantly billed for services they either weren't made aware of or made to believe were covered, only to have to fight a downhill battle once being discharged from the hospital. This place is horrible to work for, I couldn't imagine having to be a patient.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Valencia, CA
pros: Nice community hospital, work with great, professional nursing staff that work well as teams and care about patient outcomes.  Most of the doctors are nice to work with.  I don't live very far away, which promotes work/life balance.
cons: Pay and benefits package less than other hospitals in the area, but this is a one-horse town, so to speak, so unless you want to make long drives, you are kind of stuck.  I believe morale is falling due to too many changes in a very short amount of time (Lean program).  Just try walking through the halls and see all the charts written in Japanese language, and you will understand why the staff is becoming despondent and overwhelmed.   Tons of new pilot programs happening consecutively, which means even more work to an already-overstressed workflow.

review_title: CNA soon to be PCA (Patient Care Associate)
job_title: CNA in Santa Clarita, CA
pros: Workload isn’t as heavy as other hospitals, hospital is a small community, not for profit, everyone knows each other, CNA:patient ratio isn’t as high as local hospitals depending on the unit you’re in, scrub allowance provided, tuition reimbursement program.
cons:
CNA:patient ratio fluctuates daily depending on what unit you’re in, administrators rarely ever on the floor to see hard working staff, those who kiss management butt get special treatment, not all RN’s will help even if you complain that they’re detrimental to the unit, management likes to round and knit pick rather than actually solve issues, pay is lowest compared to hospitals in the San Fernando Valley, most CNA’s here have a second job, no one is held accountable here.

Hospital doesn’t require CNA Certification anymore. New job title will be Patient Care Associate meaning they can hire someone with CNA training and experience for less and train us for more duties outside of normal CNA scope of practice. Administration and upper management should’ve asked floor staff first before making such a decision! They never offered us CEU’s and now they are changing title to PCA as a cop out to not provide CEU’s. Other hospitals have CNA’s as CCP/PCA/PCT but still offer in house CEU’s.

job_title: Staff RN in Valencia, CA
pros: Warm, friendly, skilled professional nursing staff that works well together, at least on my unit.   The vast majority of doctors are nice to work with, only a couple of stinkers.  Free parking.
cons: Pay is low, and benefit package is mediocre, but I guess they have a captive audience, since no one wants to drive any farther to work.

review_title: Nice , friendly staff. Great Boss , approachable.

review_title: Welcomed by all staff and encouraged to continue my education.
